revision.comment: improve
revision.text:
{{distinguish|consumer goods}} '''Consumables''' (also known as '''consumable goods''', '''non-durable goods''', or '''soft goods''') are [[goods]] that are intended to be [[wikt:consume|consume]]d. [[John Locke]] specifies these as "consumable commodities".<ref>{{cite web|title=Consumable|url=http://onlinedictionary.datasegment.com/word/consumable|website=OnlineDictionary.DataSegment.com}}</ref> People have, for example, always consumed [[food]] and [[water]]. Consumables are in contrast to [[durable good]]s. [[Disposable]] products are a particular, extreme case of consumables, because their end-of-life is reached after a single use.
Consumables are products that [[consumer]]s use ''recurrently'', i.e., items which "get used up" or discarded. For example consumable [[office supplies]] are such products as [[paper]], [[pen]]s, [[file folder]]s, [[Post-it]] notes, and [[toner]] or [[ink cartridge]]s. This is in contrast to capital goods or [[durable good]]s in the office, such as computers, fax machines, and other business machines or office furniture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.berkeley.edu/faculty/rubinfeldd/Antitrust/FTC%20v%20Staples%20etd.pdf|title=FTC v. Staples, Inc.|website=Law.Berkeley.edu|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613094124/http://www.law.berkeley.edu/faculty/rubinfeldd/Antitrust/FTC%20v%20Staples%20etd.pdf |archivedate=2007-06-13|format=PDF}}</ref> Sometimes a company sells a durable good at an attractively low price in the hopes that the consumer will then buy the consumables that go with it at a price providing a higher [[profit margin|margin]]. Printers and ink cartridges are an example, as are [[safety razor|razors]] and [[razor|blades]], which gave this business model its usual name (the [[razor and blades model]]).
For [[arc welding]] one uses a ''consumable'' [[electrode]]. This is an electrode that conducts electricity to the [[Arc welding|arc]] but also melts into the weld as a [[filler metal]].<ref>[http://www.toolingu.com/definition-650120-36117-consumable-electrode.html Consumable] electrode, example as part of industrial process.</ref>
Consumable goods are often excluded from [[warranty]] policies, as it is considered that covering them would excessively increase the cost of the premium.<ref>e.g. batteries in computers: {{cite web | title=Apple One (1) Year Limited Warranty – Accessory - For Apple and Beats Branded Products Only. | website=Apple Legal | date=2015-08-14 | url=https://www.apple.com/uk/legal/warranty/products/accessory-warranty-english.html | ref={{sfnref | Apple Legal | 2015}} | access-date=2018-03-10|quote=This warranty excludes normal depletion of consumable parts such as batteries unless failure has occurred due to a defect in materials or workmanship and, damage resulting from abuse, accident, modifications, unauthorized repairs or other causes that are not defects in materials and workmanship.}}, {{cite web|url=https://motorola-global-portal.custhelp.com/euf/assets/downloads/AUS-One_Year_Warranty.pdf|title=AUS-One_Year_Warranty|quote=this Warranty Does Not Apply to: (a) Consumable parts, such as batteries or protective coatings designed to diminish over time unless failure has occurred due to a defect in materials or workmanship. As with all batteries, the maximum capacity of the battery will decrease with time and use;}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Fast-moving consumer goods]] * [[Principles of Intelligent Urbanism]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110725175827/http://cleanproduction.org/library/EPR_dvd/Industry_Coalition_letter.pdf Defining consumable relative to waste]
[[Category:Environmental design]] [[Category:Goods (economics)]]

{{refimprove|date=October 2014}} A '''cosmology episode''' is a sudden loss of meaning, followed eventually by a transformative pivot, which creates the conditions for revised meaning.
In the wake of the 1962 [[Cuban Missile Crisis]], the [[Vietnam War]], the 1977 [[Tenerife airport disaster]], the 1984 [[Bhopal disaster|Bhopal chemical disaster]], and the relatively sudden insertion of [[personal computers]] into the workplace, organizational scholar [[Karl E. Weick]] coined the term "cosmology episode," as follows, in 1985:
"Representations of events normally hang together sensibly within the set of assumptions that give them life and constitute a 'cosmos' rather than its opposite, a 'chaos.' Sudden losses of meaning that can occur when an event is represented electronically in an incomplete, cryptic form are what I call a 'cosmology episode.' Representations in the electronic world can become chaotic for at least two reasons: The data in these representations are flawed, and the people who manage those flawed data have limited processing capacity. These two problems interact in a potentially deadly vicious circle."<ref>Karl E. Weick. 1985. Cosmos vs. Chaos: Sense and Nonsense in Electronic Contexts. Organizational Dynamics, 14 (Autumn): 50-64</ref>
The concept of cosmology episodes evolved significantly between 1985 and 1993, when Weick published his now-classic reanalysis of [[Norman Maclean]]'s study of the [[Mann Gulch fire|Mann Gulch wildland firefighting disaster]] in 1949. In the 1993 article, Weick positions cosmology episodes within a [[constructivism (psychological school)|constructivist]] [[ontology]], he links the term to a variety of similar concepts, and he provides a better-developed definition than he was able to provide in 1985.
First, Weick makes it clear that cosmology episodes occur within a constructivist ontology of the world, rather than the more familiar [[Objectivity (philosophy)|objectivist]] and [[subjectivist]] ontologies:
"The basic idea of [[sensemaking]] is that reality is an ongoing accomplishment that emerges from efforts to create order and make retrospective sense of what occurs.... Sensemaking emphasizes that people try to make things rationally accountable to themselves and others. Thus, in the words of Morgan, Frost, and Pondy (1983: 24), "individuals are not seen as living in, and acting out their lives in relations ''to'', a wider reality, so much as creating and sustaining images of a wider reality, in part to rationalize what they are doing. They realize their reality by 'reading into' their situation patterns of significant meaning."<ref>Karl E. Weick. 1993. The Collapse of Sensemaking in Organizations: The Mann Gulch Disaster. Administrative Science Quarterly, 38: 628-652.</ref>
Second, Weick clarifies the key phrase "sudden loss of meaning" by linking it to related ideas described by other organizational scholars:
"Minimal organizations, such as we find in the crew at Mann Gulch, are susceptible to sudden losses of meaning, which have been variably described as fundamental surprises (Reason, 1990) or as events that are inconceivable (Lanir, 1989), hidden (Westrum, 1982), or incomprehensible (Perrow, 1984). Each of these labels points to the low probability that the event could occur, which is why it is meaningless. But these explanations say less about the astonishment of the perceiver, and even less about the perceiver's inability to rebuild some sense of what is happening."<ref>Karl E. Weick. 1993. The Collapse of Sensemaking in Organizations: The Mann Gulch Disaster. Administrative Science Quarterly, 38: 628-652.</ref>
Third, Weick expands his 1985 definition -- "sudden losses of meaning"—to a more nuanced description:
"Cosmology refers to a branch of philosophy often subsumed under metaphysics that combines rational speculation and scientific evidence to understand the universe as a totality of phenomena. Cosmology is the ultimate macro perspective, directed at issues of time, space, change, and contingency as they relate to the origin and structure of the universe. Integrations of these issues, however, are not just the handiwork of philosophers. Others also must make their peace with these issues, as reflected in what they take for granted. People, including those who are smokejumpers, act as if events cohere in time and space and that change unfolds in an orderly manner. These everyday cosmologies are subject to disruption. And when they are severely disrupted, I call this a cosmology episode (Weick, 1985: 51-52). A cosmology episode occurs when people suddenly and deeply feel that the universe is no longer a rational, orderly system."<ref>Karl E. Weick. 1993. The Collapse of Sensemaking in Organizations: The Mann Gulch Disaster. Administrative Science Quarterly, 38: 628-652.</ref>
== Catastrophic Cosmology Episodes == Building on Weick's 1993 definition of cosmology episodes, Weick, his colleagues, and other researchers have advanced knowledge of best practices during cosmology episodes at four levels of analysis: (1) catastrophic cosmology episodes, such as the 9/11 terrorist attacks of 2001 and the Haitian earthquake of 2010; (2) disastrous cosmology episodes, such as the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami and the 2005 Hurricane Katrina; (3) contextualized cosmology episodes occurring within specific domains, such as the 1976 Three Mile Island nuclear system incident and the 1970 [[Apollo 13]] space system incident; and (4) everyday cosmology episodes, such as transition of leaders at the top of an organization and the introduction of new technologies throughout an organization.
The study of cosmology episodes is distinct from the study of high-reliability organizations because the concept directs explicit attention to the integral role of human spirituality during catastrophic events—as the threatened entity (what now is my role in the universe?), the source of inspiration/improvisation (what now am I able to do to respond to the event?), and the re-established entity (what now is my different role in the universe?). Consequently, the topic of cosmology episodes lends itself to study by researchers within two small academic organizations—the American Psychological Association's Division 36 (Psychology of Religion and Spirituality) and the Academy of Management's MSR Division (Management, Spirituality, and Religion).
== Disastrous Cosmology Episodes == A 2016 article titled "Cosmology Episodes: A Reconceptualization," Doug Orton and Kari O'Grady identified three taxonomies that they found helpful in studying 164 citations of the term "cosmology episode" on Google Scholar. One taxonomy was based on level of analysis (nation, community, organization, team, and individual). One taxonomy was based on five resilience processes (anticipating, sense-losing, improvising, sense-remaking, and renewing). The third taxonomy -- of interest here -- is level of intensity of the cosmology episode (catastrophe, disaster, crisis, ancillary, and metaphorical). Communications researchers tend to be more present in the study of community disasters; management researchers tend to be more present in the study of organizational crises. Importantly, though, it is possible for a community-level cosmology episode to be catastrophic (e.g. Hurrican Katrina), disastrous (e.g the Red River floods of 1997), a crisis (e.g. the 22 July 2005 Stockwell Subway Shooting), ancillary (e.g. an e coli epidemic for a food company), and metaphorical (e.g. the introduction of new technology in an Italian courtroom). {{Empty section|date=October 2014}}
== Contextualized Cosmology Episode ==
{{Empty section|date=October 2014}}
== Everyday Cosmology Episodes == {{Empty section|date=October 2014}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Constructivism]] [[Category:Concepts in the philosophy of mind]] [[Category:Philosophy of life]]

page.title: Effect of Sun angle on climate

revision.comment: The "tilt" was already mentioned.
revision.text:
The amount of [[heat energy]] received at any location on the globe is a direct '''effect of Sun angle on climate''', as the [[angle of incidence (optics)|angle]] at which [[sunlight]] strikes the [[Earth]] varies by location, time of day, and [[season]] due to the [[Earth's orbit]] around the [[Sun]] and the [[Earth's rotation]] around its tilted axis. Seasonal change in the angle of sunlight, caused by the tilt of the Earth's [[axis of rotation|axis]], is the basic mechanism that results in warmer weather in summer than in winter.Windows to the Universe. [http://www.windows.ucar.edu/tour/link=/earth/climate/cli_seasons.html Earth's Tilt Is the Reason for the Seasons!] Retrieved on 2008-06-28.{{Cite journal|url=http://sites.google.com/site/khavrus/public-activities/SolarEng|last=Khavrus|first=V.|title=Introduction to solar motion geometry on the basis of a simple model|year=2010|journal=Physics Education|volume=45|doi=10.1088/0031-9120/45/6/010|page=641|last2=Shelevytsky|first2=I.|issue=6|bibcode = 2010PhyEd..45..641K }}{{Cite journal|url=http://sites.google.com/site/khavrus/public-activities/seasons|last=Khavrus|first=V.|title=Geometry and the physics of seasons|year=2012|journal=Physics Education|volume=47|doi=10.1088/0031-9120/47/6/680|page=680|last2=Shelevytsky|first2=I.|issue=6 }} Change in [[day length]] is another factor. (See also [[season]].) == Geometry of Sun angle == [[Image:seasons.too.png|thumb|400px|right|'''Figure 2'''
One sunbeam one mile wide shines on the ground at a 90° angle, and another at a 30° angle. The one at a shallower angle covers twice as much area with the same amount of light energy.]] When sunlight shines on the earth at a lower [[angle of incidence (optics)|angle]] (Sun closer to the horizon), the energy of the sunlight is spread over a larger area, and is therefore weaker than if the Sun is higher overhead and the energy is concentrated on a smaller area. '''Figure 2''' depicts a sunbeam one mile (1.6 km) wide falling on the ground from directly overhead, and another hitting the ground at a 30° angle. [[Trigonometry]] tells us that the [[sine]] of a 30° angle is 1/2, whereas the sine of a 90° angle is 1. Therefore, the sunbeam hitting the ground at a 30° angle spreads the same amount of light over twice as much area (if we imagine the Sun shining from the south at [[noon]], the north-south width doubles; the east-west width does not). Consequently, the amount of light falling on each square mile is only half as much. [[Image:seasons.svg|right|250px|thumb|'''Figure 3'''
This is a diagram of the seasons. Regardless of the time of day (i.e. the [[Earth]]'s rotation on its axis), the [[North Pole]] will be dark, and the [[South Pole]] will be illuminated; see also [[arctic winter]].]] '''Figure 3''' shows the angle of sunlight striking the earth in the [[Northern hemisphere|Northern]] and [[southern hemisphere|Southern]] hemispheres when the Earth's northern axis is tilted away from the Sun, when it is winter in the north and summer in the south. ===Technical note=== [[Thermal radiation|Heat energy]] is not received from the Sun. Rather, [[Solar radiation|radiant energy]] is received and this results in change in [[Thermal energy|energy level]] of receiving bodies in Earth's domain. Different materials have different properties for transmitting back received energy in the form of ''heat energy'' at different rates. ==See also== * [[Insolation]] * [[Axial tilt]] * [[Declination]] * [[Sun path]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Climate]] [[Category:Seasons]] [[Category:Atmospheric radiation]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 870558258 by [[Special:Contributions/Kajan Lakhan|Kajan Lakhan]] ([[User talk:Kajan Lakhan|talk]]) it is the right tense he showed something that is still correct
revision.text:
'''Electron degeneracy pressure''' is a particular manifestation of the more general phenomenon of [[quantum degeneracy]] pressure. The [[Pauli exclusion principle]] disallows two identical half-integer [[spin (physics)|spin]] particles ([[electron]]s and all other [[fermion]]s) from simultaneously occupying the same [[quantum state]]. The result is an emergent pressure against compression of [[matter]] into smaller [[volume]]s of space. Electron degeneracy pressure results from the same underlying mechanism that defines the electron orbital structure of elemental matter. For bulk matter with no net electric charge, the attraction between electrons and nuclei exceeds (at any scale) the mutual repulsion of electrons plus the mutual repulsion of nuclei; so absent electron degeneracy pressure, the matter would collapse into a single nucleus. In 1967, [[Freeman Dyson]] showed that solid matter is stabilized by quantum degeneracy pressure rather than electrostatic repulsion.<ref name="Dyson1967a">{{cite journal | title=Stability of Matter I |author1=Dyson, F. J. |author2=Lenard, A. | journal=J. Math. Phys. |date=March 1967 | volume=8 | issue=3 | pages=423–434 | doi=10.1063/1.1705209|bibcode = 1967JMP.....8..423D }}</ref><ref name="Lenard1968">{{cite journal | title=Stability of Matter II |author1=Lenard, A. |author2=Dyson, F. J. | journal=J. Math. Phys. |date=May 1968 | volume=9 | issue=5 | pages=698–711 | doi=10.1063/1.1664631|bibcode = 1968JMP.....9..698L }}</ref><ref name="Dyson1967b">{{cite journal | title=Ground‐State Energy of a Finite System of Charged Particles | author=Dyson, F. J. | journal=J. Math. Phys. |date=August 1967 | volume=8 | issue=8 | pages=1538–1545 | doi=10.1063/1.1705389|bibcode = 1967JMP.....8.1538D }}</ref> Because of this, electron degeneracy creates a barrier to the gravitational collapse of dying stars and is responsible for the formation of [[white dwarf]]s.
== From the uncertainty principle == Perhaps useful in appreciating electron degeneracy pressure is the [[Heisenberg uncertainty principle]], which states that :<math>\Delta x \Delta p \ge \frac{\hbar}{2} </math>, where Δ''x'' is the uncertainty ([[standard deviation]]) of the position measurements, Δ''p'' is the uncertainty of the [[momentum]] measurements, and ''ħ'' is the reduced [[Planck constant]].
A material subjected to ever-increasing pressure will compact more, and, for electrons within it, their delocalization, Δ''x'', will decrease. Thus, as dictated by the uncertainty principle, the spread in the momenta of the electrons, Δ''p'', will grow. Thus, no matter how low the temperature drops, the electrons must be travelling at these large "Heisenberg speeds", contributing to the pressure.{{Vague|date=October 2018}} When the pressure due to this "Heisenberg motion" exceeds that of the pressure from the thermal motions of the electrons, the electrons are referred to as degenerate, and the material is termed [[degenerate matter]]. This analysis is true even at almost zero temperature.
== From the Fermi gas theory == {{main|Fermi gas}} Electrons are part of a family of particles known as [[fermion]]s. Fermions like the [[proton]] or the [[neutron]] follow Pauli's principle and [[Fermi–Dirac statistics]]. In general, for an ensemble of non-interacting fermions, also known as [[Fermi gas]], each particle can be treated independently with an energy given by the purely kinetic term, :<math>E = \frac{p^2}{2m},</math> where {{math|''p''}} is the momentum of one particle and {{math|''m''}} its mass. Every possible momentum state of an electron within this volume up to the Fermi momentum {{math|''p''<sub>F</sub>}} being occupied.
The degeneracy pressure at zero temperature can be computed as<ref>{{cite book|last=Griffiths|title=Introduction to Quantum Mechanics|year=1994|publisher=[[Prentice Hall]]|location=London, UK|isbn=0131244051}}Equation 5.46</ref> :<math>P= \frac{2}{3}\frac{E_\text{tot}}{V}=\frac{2}{3}\frac{p_{\rm{F}}^5}{10 \pi^2 m \hbar^3} ,</math>
where ''V'' is the total volume of the system and ''E''<sub>tot</sub> is the total energy of the ensemble. Specifically for the electron degeneracy pressure, {{math|''m''}} is substituted by the electron mass {{math|''m''<sub>e</sub>}} and the Fermi momentum is obtained from the [[Fermi energy]], so the electron degeneracy pressure is given by :<math>P_e=\frac{(3 \pi^2)^{2/3} \hbar^2}{5 m_e}\rho_e^{5/3}</math>, where {{math|''ρ''<sub>''e''</sub>}} is the free electron [[Number density|density]] (the number of free electrons per unit volume). For the case of a metal, one can prove that this equation remains approximately true for temperatures lower than the Fermi temperature, about {{math|10<sup>6</sup>}} [[kelvin]].
When particle energies reach [[Special relativity|relativistic]] levels, a modified formula is required. The relativistic degeneracy pressure is proportional to {{math|''ρ''<sub>''e''</sub><sup>4/3</sup>}}.
== Examples ==
=== Metals === For the case of electrons in [[Crystal|crystalline solid]], several approximations are carefully justified to treat the electrons as independent particles. Usual models are the [[free electron model]] and the [[nearly free electron model]]. In the appropriate systems, the electron degeneracy pressure can be calculated and can be shown that this pressure is an important contribution to the compressibility or [[bulk modulus]] of metals.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/934604|title=Solid state physics|last=Neil W.|first=Ashcroft|last2=Mermin|first2=N. David.|date=1976|publisher=Holt, Rinehart and Winston|others=|year=|isbn=0030839939|location=New York|pages=39|oclc=934604|author-link=Neil Ashcroft|author-link2=N. David Mermin}}</ref>
=== White dwarfs ===
Electron degeneracy pressure will halt the gravitational collapse of a star if its mass is below the [[Chandrasekhar limit]] (1.44 [[solar masses]]<ref name="Mazzali2007">{{cite journal |author1=Mazzali, P. A. |author2=K. Röpke, F. K. |author3=Benetti, S. |author4=Hillebrandt, W. | title=A Common Explosion Mechanism for Type Ia Supernovae | journal=Science | year=2007 | volume=315 | issue=5813 | pages=825–828 | doi=10.1126/science.1136259 | pmid=17289993 | postscript=. | bibcode=2007Sci...315..825M|arxiv = astro-ph/0702351 }}</ref>). This is the pressure that prevents a [[white dwarf]] star from collapsing. A star exceeding this limit and without significant thermally generated pressure will continue to collapse to form either a [[neutron star]] or [[black hole]], because the degeneracy pressure provided by the electrons is weaker than the inward pull of [[gravity]].
== See also == * [[Exchange interaction]] * [[Fermi level]] * [[Bose–Einstein condensate]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Pauli exclusion principle]] [[Category:Stellar evolution]] [[Category:White dwarfs]]

revision.comment: References
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=January 2011}} The '''European Soil Database''' is the main source of [[soil]] information from which most other data information and services are derived [[Geographic_information_system]]. For instance, the '''European Soil Database v2 Raster Archive''' contains raster (grid) data files with cell sizes of 10km x 10km for a large number of soil related parameters. Each grid is aligned with the INSPIRE reference grid recommended in the 1st Workshop on European Reference Grids. These rasters are in the public domain and allow expert users to use the data for instance to run soil-, water- and air related models. The 10km x 10km grids fit with ideas from [[INSPIRE]] to develop “nested” systems for re-porting and updating European soil data at different scales, according to a hierarchy of grids with a common point of origin and standardized location and size of grid cells. The European Soil Database may be downloaded from the [http://esdac.jrc.ec.europa.eu European Soil Data Center] (ESDAC)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Panagos|first=Panos|last2=Liedekerke|first2=Marc Van|last3=Jones|first3=Arwyn|last4=Montanarella|first4=Luca|title=European Soil Data Centre: Response to European policy support and public data requirements|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0264837711000718|journal=Land Use Policy|volume=29|issue=2|pages=329–338|doi=10.1016/j.landusepol.2011.07.003}}</ref>.
The soil raster data files are accompanied by as many static soil maps (PDF Format, A3), which allow the user to have a quick overview of the distribution of soil characteristics in a spatial way. One of the main outputs of the ESBN has been a series of documents and research reports. All these are now on-line for public download.
Additionally, a number of mapping services has been developed in order to allow the general public to navigate and query soil data. The SOMIS (SOil Map Internet Service) is a web-based application for the navigation of ESDB related data through a map interface. This map service allows interaction through soil parameter selection and map operations such as zooming and panning. The data can be queried and identified; advanced printing capabilities are provided. According to [[INSPIRE]] principles, this application has been created and extended so that it is possible to combine layers of maps located in different map servers all around the World, based on International [[Web Map Service]] (WMS) standards and specifications from the [[Open GIS Consortium]], as also laid down in the INSPIRE Guidelines, in order to attain the maximum interoperability of data and services.
'''Download Sources''': * [https://esdac.jrc.ec.europa.eu/content/european-soil-database-v20-vector-and-attribute-data Vector Data] * [https://esdac.jrc.ec.europa.eu/content/european-soil-database-v2-raster-library-1kmx1km Raster Library 1km x 1km] * [https://esdac.jrc.ec.europa.eu/content/european-soil-database-v2-raster-library-10kmx10km Raster Library 10kmx10km] * [https://esdac.jrc.ec.europa.eu/content/legend-files Legend Files]
== See also == *[[European Soil Bureau Network]]
==References== <references />
== External links == * [http://esdac.jrc.ec.europa.eu/ Official site] * [https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.landusepol.2011.07.003 European Soil Data Centre: response to European policy support and public data requirements] Land Use Policy, 29 (2), pp. 329-338. * [http://eusoils.jrc.ec.europa.eu/esbn/Esbn_overview.html European Soil Bureau Network] * LUCAS topsoil database: {{Cite journal|last=Orgiazzi|first=A.|last2=Ballabio|first2=C.|last3=Panagos|first3=P.|last4=Jones|first4=A.|last5=Fernández-Ugalde|first5=O.|title=LUCAS Soil, the largest expandable soil dataset for Europe: a review|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ejss.12499/abstract|journal=European Journal of Soil Science|language=en|pages=n/a–n/a|doi=10.1111/ejss.12499|issn=1365-2389}} * [http://www.geoconnexion.com/uploads/europeansoil_intv5i7.pdf The European soil database] Geo: International, July/Aug 2006 Volume 5 · Issue 7: 32-33. Pan-European in scope, this database provides a consistent view and understanding of the soil we depend upon for living.
[[Category:Geographic information systems]] [[Category:Geography of Europe]] [[Category:Government databases of the European Union]] [[Category:Pedology]] [[Category:Soil]] [[Category:Geographical databases]] [[Category:Databases in Europe]]

revision.text:
{{Eastern Slavic name|Filippovich|Konyukhov}} [[File:Fyodor Konyukhov 2018-06-27.jpg|thumb|250px|Fedor Konyukhov, 2018]] '''Fedor Filippovich Konyukhov''' ({{lang-ru|Фёдор Филиппович Конюхов}}; born December 12, 1951 in [[:uk:Чкалове (Приазовський район)|Chkalovo]], [[Pryazovskyi Raion]], [[Zaporizhia Oblast]], [[Ukrainian SSR]]) is a Russian survivalist, voyager, aerial and marine explorer, and artist. In December 2010, he was ordained as an [[Russian Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox]] priest in the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sputniknews.com/voiceofrussia/2012/02/01/65053404/|title=Konyukhov plans 2nd Everest ascent|date=1 February 2012|publisher=}}</ref>
==Personal life== Konyukhov was born in the village of [[:uk:Чкалове (Приазовський район)|Chkalovo]], located in the [[Pryazovskyi Raion]] of [[Ukraine]]'s [[Zaporizhia Oblast]]. His father was a fisherman on the [[Sea of Azov]], while his grandfather had served in the same garrison as [[Georgy Sedov]], an Arctic explorer. Konyukhov attended a nautical school in [[Odessa]] and another in [[Leningrad]] earning a specialty in polar navigation. Subsequently, he worked as a professional navigator and marine engineer.<ref name="rt">[http://russiapedia.rt.com/prominent-russians/exploring-russia/fyodor-konyukhov/ Prominent Russians: Fyodor Konyukhov]. [[Russia Today]]. Retrieved 24 July 2016.</ref> He served 3 years in the [[Soviet Navy]]. He was stationed in a [[Kaliningrad]] guardhouse with the [[Baltic Fleet]] when he volunteered for a 2.5 year tour of duty as a [[Naval Infantry (Russia)#Soviet era|Soviet Marine]] sailing across the [[South China Sea]] as [[Spetsnaz GRU|special forces]] delivering munitions to the [[Viet Cong]] during the [[Vietnam War]].<ref name=nam>{{cite web | title = Вокруг Cвета и Oбратно: Федор Конюхов | url = http://planeta.by/article/1501 | language = Russian | trans-title = Around the World and Back: Fyodor Konyukhov | publisher = Planeta.by | date = June 2015 | accessdate = July 29, 2016}}</ref> After his service in the [[Soviet Armed Forces]], he disliked the terrible realities of war and completed a vocational arts school in [[Babruysk|Bobruisk]] which enabled him to become a successful painter and sculptor.<ref name = nam/> Konyukhov is an ordained priest in the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]]. He was made a [[deacon]] in 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/russia-and-former-soviet-union/russian-traveler-fyodor-konyukhov-ordained-to-deac-67533.html "Russian traveler Fyodor Konyukhov ordained to deaconship"]. Kyiv Post. 24 May 2010. Retrieved 24 July 2016.</ref>
== Art == In 1983, Fedor Konyukhov was admitted to the Union of Artists of the USSR (he was the youngest member at that moment). Since 1996 he has been a member of the Moscow Union of Artists, Graphic Arts section; since 2001, a member of the Sculpture section as well.<ref name=Bio>{{cite web | title = Fedor Konyukhov: Biography | url = http://konyukhov.ru/en/biography.html | publisher = konyukhov.ru | accessdate = July 29, 2016}}</ref>
He is a winner of the Gold Medal of the Russian Arts Academy, an Honorary Academician of the Russian Arts Academy and the creator of more than 3,000 paintings. He has participated in a number of Russian and international exhibitions.<ref name=Bio/>
Fedor Konyukhov becomes the first priest of the Russian Orthodox Church to successfully climbed Mt. Everest. He took the icon of St. Nicholas to the Summit with him.
2015 - Global Ambassadors for Australia Zoo Wildlife Warriors.<ref name=Bio/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mmoma.ru/en/exhibitions/gogolevsky/fyodor_konyukhov_paintings_and_graphics/|title=Paintings and graphics|website=www.mmoma.ru|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref>
== Feats == Konyukhov is the only person{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} to have reached such extreme points of the planet as the [[North Pole]] (three times), the [[South Pole]], the [[Pole of Inaccessibility in the Arctic Ocean]] and the top of [[Mount Everest]] (twice) and also sailed around the world via [[Cape Horn]] 4 times.
===Sailing=== In May 2008, Konyukhov completed a solo circumnavigation of [[Antarctica]] in a sailboat, becoming the first person to do so. His attempt began on 26 January 2008 and took 102 days in total, with his route falling entirely between the [[45th parallel south|45th]] and [[60th parallel south|60th parallels south]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Simon Brown |title= Fedor finishes solo Antarctic sail |url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2008/05/07/2238308.htm |accessdate=23 July 2016 |publisher=ABC News |date=7 May 2008}}</ref>
===Rowing=== Konyukhov has set world records, notably crossing the Atlantic Ocean in a row-boat URALAZ in 46 days,<ref name="CalkhovenHerndon2006">{{cite book|last1=Calkhoven|first1=Laurie|last2=Herndon|first2=Ryan|title=Guinness world records fearless feats: incredible records of human achievement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3uLSlKEqtU8C|accessdate=21 September 2011|date=2006-02-01|publisher=Scholastic|isbn=978-0-439-71565-2|page=19}}</ref> the best 24-hour distance in the same boat (110 miles).
From December 22, 2013 to May 31, 2014 Fyodor Konyukhov crossed the Pacific Ocean starting in the Chilean port of Concon and finishing in Australian town of Mooloolaba (Sunshine Coast) without entering ports and without any external help or assistance. He covered the distance of more than 17,408 km (9400 nautical miles) on the Turgoyak (K9) rowboat in just 162 days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/162728-konyukhov-finish-voyage-pacific/|title=62 yo Russian solo sailor crosses Pacific on rowboat covering 17,000km in just 162 days|publisher=}}</ref>
===Ballooning=== On 23 July 2016, Konyukhov became the second person to [[Circumnavigation|circumnavigate]] the world in a [[Hot air balloon#Hybrid|hybrid hot-air helium balloon]].<ref name=cameron/> American [[Steve Fossett]] is the only other person to have completed the feat, having done so in 2002 on his sixth attempt. Konyukhov took "just over 11 days", as opposed to Fossett's 13 days.<ref>{{cite news |title=Russian adventurer breaks world hot air balloon record |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-23/russian-adventurer-lands-hot-air-balloon-in-wa/7654812 |accessdate=23 July 2016 |work=ABC News |publisher=ABC-Australia |date=23 July 2016}}</ref>
Konyukhov announced his intention to challenge Fossett's record in September 2015,<ref>{{cite news |author=Bruce Atkinson |title=Russian adventurer Fedor Konyukhov sets sights on around-the-world solo balloon record |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-09-24/russian-adventurer-fedor-konyukhov-sets-sights-on-balloon-record/6800552 |accessdate=24 July 2016 |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=24 September 2015}}</ref> although the idea had "first captured [his] imagination in 1992".<ref name="ng">{{cite news |author=Andrew Bisharat |title= Russian Adventurer Completes Round-the-World Ballooning Record |url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/activities/aerial-sports/hot-air-balloon-circumnaviation-record-fedor-konyukhov/ |accessdate=24 July 2016 |publisher=[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] |date=22 July 2016}}</ref> The balloon he used, named the ''Morton'', was specially constructed by [[Cameron Balloons]] in [[Bristol]], England,<ref>{{cite news |author=|title= Around-the-world helium balloon build begins in Bristol |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-bristol-34540637 |accessdate=24 July 2016 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=16 October 2015}}</ref> and had a height of {{Convert|60|m|ft}} and a volume of {{convert|15500|m3|cuyd}}. The balloon's non-pressurised [[Gondola (balloon)|gondola]] was made of [[carbon fibre]] and measured roughly {{Convert|2|m|ft}} wide and {{Convert|2|m|ft}} tall, containing Konyukhov's bed, food, water, oxygen, and first-aid supplies, as well as navigation and communication equipment.<ref name="ng"/>
The attempt began in [[Northam, Western Australia]], {{Convert|96|km|mi}} north-east of [[Perth]], on 12 July 2016.<ref>{{cite news |author=Briana Shepherd |title=Russian adventurer Fedor Konyukhov prepares to launch solo hot-air balloon mission in WA |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-11/russian-fedor-konyukhov-hot-air-balloon-globe/7586500 |accessdate=24 July 2016 |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=11 July 2016}}</ref> He and his team had arrived in Australia in June, but experienced several delays due to weather and the failure of equipment to arrive on time.<ref>{{cite news |author=Sarah Taillier |title=Russian balloon record tilt held up by Perth customs 'delay' |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-06-13/russian-balloon-record-tilt-held-up-by-perth-customs-delay/7506386 |accessdate=24 July 2016 |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=13 June 2016}}</ref> After launching, Konyukhov flew east across Australia and the [[South Pacific Ocean]] to South America, where he passed through Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, and the southern tip of Brazil. He then flew across the [[South Atlantic Ocean|South Atlantic]], the southern [[Indian Ocean]], and the [[Southern Ocean]] before eventually landing again in [[Bonnie Rock, Western Australia]], completing his circumnavigation.<ref>[http://konyukhov.ru/en/roadmap.html "Around the World on Roziere Balloon". Fedor Konyukhov. Retrieved 24 July 2016.]</ref> Konyukhov's planned route was {{Convert|33000|km|mi}}, but an unexpected southerly deviation (which took him to the [[Antarctic Circle]]) extended his flight to {{Convert|34000|km|mi}}.<ref>{{cite news |author=|title=Fedor Konyukhov breaks world hot air balloon record |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/fedor-konyukhov-breaks-world-hot-air-balloon-record-160723101753237.html |accessdate=24 July 2016 |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |date=23 July 2016}}</ref>
He set a new round-the world time of 272h 11m,<ref name=cameron>{{cite web |url=http://www.cameronballoons.co.uk/news/new-round-the-world-adventure |title=World Record - Round-The-World Flight|website=Cameron Balloons|date= 15 August 2016 |author= |accessdate= 17 September 2016}}</ref> {{As of|2016|9|17|lc=y}} subject to official confirmation.<ref name=record-ballooning>{{cite web |url = http://www.fai.org/record-ballooning |title = Balloon World Records |publisher = Fédération Aéronautique Internationale |accessdate = 17 September 2016 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160908172221/http://www.fai.org/record-ballooning |archivedate = 8 September 2016 |df = }}</ref> He described his experience in a newspaper article.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/sep/16/experience-flew-solo-round-world-hot-air-balloon |title=Experience: I flew solo around the world in a hot-air balloon |newspaper=The Guardian |date=17 September 2016|author=Fedor Konyukhov |accessdate= 17 September 2016}} Article by Konyukhov describing the experience.</ref>
===Others=== {{BLP sources section|date=July 2016}} 2000 (March) – Completed the longest dog race IDITAROD – 1150 miles from Anchorage to Nome (Northern route)
2007 (May) - Dog sled expedition across Greenland Ice Cap from East to West. Started from Isortoq (East Coast) and finished at West Coast (Ilullisat). Covering about 800 km in 15 days and 22 hours during a Trans-[[Greenland]] dog sleigh ride.
2013 (April–May) – Dog sled expedition from North Pole to Canada. Together with his partner - Viktor Simonov they crossed Arctic Ocean in 46 days and reached the shores of Ward Hunt Island (Canada).
In 2011 Konyukhov fulfilled an expedition cross Ethiopia, covering more than 1000 km of route.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pravoslavie.ru/english/46224.htm|title=Fr. Feodor Koniukhov concludes his expedition through Ethiopia / OrthoChristian.Com|publisher=}}</ref>
== Explorers Grand Slam == Fedor is the first Russian mountaineer to complete the [[Seven Summits|7 Summits challenge]] for which a person must climb the highest mountains of each of the seven major continents, also he is the first Russian traveller and third person in the world, who completed The [[Explorers Grand Slam]]: he also visited both the [[North Pole]] and the [[South Pole]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://guinnessworldrecords.com/news/2016/7/russian-explorer-set-to-break-circumnavigation-record-in-hot-air-balloon-436872|title=Russian explorer set to break circumnavigation record in hot air balloon|date=2016-07-22|work=Guinness World Records|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en-GB}}</ref> * 1992 (26 of February) — [[Mount Elbrus]] (Europe/Russia) * 1992 (14 of May) — [[Mount Everest]] (Asia) — (in the AvtoVAZ team) * 1996 (19 of January) — [[Vinson Massif]] (Antarctica) * 1996 (09 of March) — [[Aconcagua]] (South America) * 1997 (18 of February) — [[Mount Kilimanjaro]] (Africa) * 1997 (17 of April) — [[Mount Kosciuszko]] (Australia) * 1997 (26 of May) — [[Denali]] (formerly Mt. McKinley, North America) — (in the team) On May 19, 2012 - Fedor Konyukhov together with the Russian team "7 Summits" reached the top of Mt. Everest. His climbing route was via the Northern Ridge (Tibet). This expedition was devoted to the 20th anniversary of the first Russian ascent of Mt. Everest (via the Southern Col) – May 1992.
== Awards == * [[File:Order_friendship_of_peoples_rib.png|72x72px]] [[Order of Friendship of Peoples]]. {{citation needed|date=July 2016}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{commons category|Fyodor Konyukhov}} * {{official website|http://konyukhov.ru/eng/}} * [http://en.rian.ru/analysis/20050809/41124131.html RIA Novosti: Fyodor Konyukhov: The Russian dead-end of rationalism] * [http://www.fedor-konyuhov.livejournal.com/ Fyodor Konyukhov's official blog about the expedition on a rowing boat across the Pacific ocean]
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/142.46.32.226|142.46.32.226]] ([[User talk:142.46.32.226|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
:''This article is about an [[ecozone]]. For the landform covering the same general region, see [[Hudson Bay Lowland]]. The '''Hudson Plains Ecozone''', as defined by the [[Commission for Environmental Cooperation]] (CEC), is a sparsely populated [[Canada|Canadian]] subarctic [[Ecozones of Canada|ecozone]] extending from the western coast of [[Quebec]] to the coast of [[Manitoba]], encompassing all coastal areas of [[James Bay]] and those of southern [[Hudson Bay]], stretching to about [[50th parallel north|50°N latitude]]. It includes the largest continuous [[wetland]] in the world.<ref name="bernhardt">{{Cite web |url=http://canadianbiodiversity.mcgill.ca/english/ecozones/hudsonplains/hudsonplains.htm |title=Hudson Plains |work=Canada's Ecozones, Canadian Biodiversity project |last=Bernhardt |first=Torsten |publisher=[[McGill University]], Redpath Museum |accessdate=2008-02-01}}</ref> It covers nearly a quarter of [[Ontario]]'s landmass, and 3.6% of Canada's total area,<ref name="area">{{Cite web |url = http://www.environnement-canada.ca/soer-ree/English/SOER/1996report/Doc/1-6-2-4-1.cfm |title = The State of Canada's Environment — 1996 |publisher = [[Environment Canada]] |accessdate = 2008-02-01 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> totalling approximately 369,000 square kilometres of land and 11,800 square kilometres of water.<ref name="general">{{Cite web |url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/soer-ree/English/Vignettes/Terrestrial/hp/default.cfm |title=The Wetlands |work=Hudson Plains Ecozone |publisher=[[Environment Canada]] |accessdate=2008-02-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804114914/http://www.ec.gc.ca/soer-ree/English/Vignettes/Terrestrial/hp/default.cfm |archivedate=2007-08-04}}</ref> Its historical prominence is due to the harshness endured by pioneer explorers who established fortifications for [[Hudson's Bay Company]], and as a result of regional wars between France and Britain.<ref name="general" /> Today, it is primarily noted for the well-known [[Polar Bear Provincial Park]], and to a lesser extent [[Wapusk National Park]], as well as its vast wetlands which are used by [[Bird migration|migratory birds]].
==Geography== The [[Palaeozoic]] and [[Proterozoic]] [[sedimentation|sedimentary]] deposits overlaying the [[bedrock]]<ref name="bernhardt" /> have formed into a wide and level plain characterised by [[raised beach]]es and [[river delta]]s,<ref name="sedimentary">{{Cite web |url=https://www.gov.mb.ca/conservation/annual-report/soe-reports/soe97/soe97.html |title=State of the Environment Reports |publisher=[[Manitoba Environment]] |year=1997 |accessdate=2008-02-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811042717/http://www.gov.mb.ca/conservation/annual-report/soe-reports/soe97/soe97.html |archivedate=2007-08-11}}</ref> with an elevation rarely exceeding 120 m.<ref name="ECO">{{Cite web |url=http://www.eco.on.ca/english/aboutont/hudson.htm |title=Hudson Plains |work=The Ecozones of Ontario |publisher=Environmental Commissioner of Ontario |accessdate=2008-02-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070923052805/http://www.eco.on.ca/english/aboutont/hudson.htm |archivedate=2007-09-23 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The relatively flat land slopes gently toward the two bays, which act as a [[drainage basin]] for the region. However, the relatively poor drainage system has spurred the natural development of numerous [[wetland]]s. It is encircled by the [[Canadian Shield]], with which it overlaps in a few areas to the east and west.<ref name="Canadianshield">{{Cite web |url = http://www.bsc-eoc.org/international/bcrs/7.html |title = Taiga Shield & Hudson Plains |work = Canadian Bird Conservation Regions |publisher = Bird Studies Canada |accessdate = 2008-02-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080908023404/http://www.bsc-eoc.org/international/bcrs/7.html |archivedate = 2008-09-08 |df = }}</ref>
To its north is the cold [[Arctic Archipelago Marine]] ecozone, and to the south is the milder [[Boreal Shield]]. Hence, this ecozone is transitional,<ref name="ECO" /> which is easily evident as it transforms from [[Barren vegetation|barren]] [[tundra]] in the north to open [[taiga]] [[forest]]s in the south.<ref name="bernhardt" /> These forests resemble those of the [[boreal ecosystem|boreal]] zone, with sparser [[vegetation]].<ref name="ECO" />
Thousands of depressions carved by retreating [[glacier]]s have become [[lake]]s and wetlands.<ref name="Canadianshield" /> The Hudson Plains is also noted for [[coastal marsh]]es and extensive [[tidal flat]]s,<ref name="Canadianshield" /> with [[tidal marsh]]es along the coast of Hudson Bay.<ref name="sedimentary" /> Belts of [[raised beach]]es are evident where rebound from glacier retreat is most prominent.<ref name="ECO" />
==Climate== The ecozone has a [[subarctic climate]] which is significantly influenced by the adjacent marine area of Hudson Bay, which features cold and moisture-laden low-pressure systems.<ref name="coldair">{{Cite web |url = http://www.pc.gc.ca/apprendre-learn/prof/itm2-crp-trc/pdf/ecozone08_e.pdf |format = PDF |title = Hudson Plains Ecozone |publisher = [[Parks Canada]] |date = Autumn 2003 |accessdate = 2008-02-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110605103447/http://www.pc.gc.ca/apprendre-learn/prof/itm2-crp-trc/pdf/ecozone08_e.pdf |archivedate = 2011-06-05 |df = }}</ref> Frigid polar high-pressure air masses commonly reach the area. Typically cold, mean January temperatures are near −19 °C, and mean July temperatures range between 12 °C and 16 °C. The region experiences moderate [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]], between 400 mm to 700 mm annually.<ref name="coldair" /> Summers are cool and relatively short, with prolonged daylight,<ref name="Canadianshield" /> while winters are very cold.<!-- portions of this should be incorporated into the text: A high water table, underlying permafrost, the maritime climatic influence and the low, coastal terrain are just a few of the factors that produce a frigid, wet, subarctic environment.<ref name="sedimentary" />-->
==Flora and fauna== Referred to as an "insect-infested landscape of [[bog]] and [[fog]]",<ref name="general" /> it teems with large [[insect]] populations that are a food source for migratory [[Anatidae|waterbirds]].<ref name="ECO" /> The Hudson Plains have become "notorious for their populations of biting insects".<ref name="bernhardt" /> Vegetation is somewhat limited, with the northern areas abutting the Arctic Archipelago Marine being nearly treeless, whereas the southern extent, adjacent to the Boreal Shield, have open forest.<ref name="CWF">{{Cite web |url=http://www.wildaboutgardening.org/en/growing/section3/ecozone_map/index.htm |title=Ecozones |publisher=Canadian Wildlife Federation |accessdate=2008-02-01}}</ref> [[Alder]], [[willow]], [[black spruce]] and [[tamarack]] are the most common plant species in the treed bogs and [[fen]]s of the Hudson Plains,<ref name="Canadianshield" /><ref name="CWF" /> whereas [[sphagnum]] and [[shrub]]s such as [[crowberry]] and [[blueberry]] dominate the open bogs to the north,<ref name="sedimentary" /><ref name="CWF" /> with [[white spruce]] appearing further south. Poorly drained areas produce dense sedge, moss and lichen cover.<ref name="Canadianshield" />
The Hudson Plains also represent the southern extent of the [[polar bear]]s yearly migratory route, which reaches the northwestern coast of Ontario. In autumn, polar bears migrate to the [[ice back]] forming along the coast of Hudson Bay.<ref>C. Michael Hogan (2008) [http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=36084 ''Polar Bear: Ursus maritimus''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081224205716/http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=36084 |date=2008-12-24 }}, Globaltwitcher.com, ed. Nicklas Stromberg</ref> The bears then follow the Hudson Bay Coast toward [[Churchill, Manitoba|Churchill]], [[Manitoba]]. [[Mammal]]s such as [[moose]], [[woodland caribou]] and [[American black bear|black bear]]s are comfortable in this environment, but smaller mammals are more common, including [[muskrat]]s, [[weasel]]s, [[Arctic fox]]es, [[marten]]s, and [[Fisher (animal)|fishers]].<ref name="coldair" /><ref name="CWF" />
The adjacent marine ecozone of the Arctic Archipelago Marine supports mammal populations of [[walrus]] and [[Bearded seal|bearded]], [[Harbour seal|harbour]] and [[Ringed seal|ringed]] seals.<ref name="coldair" />
Millions of migratory [[Wader|shorebirds]] stage and nest in multiple areas of the Hudson Plains, particularly in three areas within [[Southern James Bay]]: [[Akimiski Island]], and the migratory bird sanctuaries at [[Hannah Bay]] and the mouth of the [[Moose River (Ontario)|Moose River]]. Representative species include the [[snow goose]], [[Canada goose]], [[king eider]], [[swan]], [[loon]], [[gyrfalcon]], and [[peregrine falcon]].<ref name="coldair" /><ref name="CWF" />
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{coord missing|Ontario}}
[[Category:Taiga and boreal forests]] [[Category:Tundra]] [[Category:Wetlands of Ontario]] [[Category:Ecozones of Canada]] [[Category:Geography of Northern Ontario]] [[Category:Plains of Canada]]

revision.comment: Fix caps in section header and other minor fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
:''"Ion pump" redirects here. For a protein that moves ions across a plasma membrane, see [[Ion transporter]]. An ion pump is not to be confused with an [[ionic liquid piston pump]] or an ionic [[liquid ring]] vacuum pump.'' An '''ion pump''' (also referred to as a '''sputter ion pump''') is a type of [[vacuum pump]] capable of reaching pressures as low as 10<sup>−11</sup> mbar under ideal conditions.<ref name=Varian>{{cite web|url=http://www.agilent.com/cs/library/catalogs/public/06_Ion_Pumps.pdf|format=PDF|title=Ion Pumps|publisher=[[Agilent]]}}</ref> An ion pump [[ionization|ionizes]] gas within the vessel it is attached to and employs a strong electrical potential, typically 3–7 kV, which allows the ions to accelerate into and be captured by a solid electrode and its residue.
==Early history== The first ion pump was invented by [[Varian Associates]], now [[Agilent]]. The original activity of Varian, co-founded in 1948 by Russell Varian, the inventor of the [[Klystron]], and his brother Sigurd, was in the field of microwave electron tubes. Robert Jepsen joined the company in 1951 and soon became director of the Klystron research group. His investigation about electronic vacuum pumping led in 1957 to the realization of the first sputter ion pump (SIP), later named VacIon pump, of which he was co-inventor. The pump was developed as an appendage pump for maintaining Ultra High Vacuum (UHV) in microwave power tubes after processing, but soon after honeycomb-shaped anodes and commercial VacIon pumps with speeds of thousands of liters per second were produced. Lewis Hall and John Helmer were members of the research team, involved in the choice of the most suitable cathode material and in the optimization of the ion pump design. Sherm Rutherford joined Varian in February 1959 in the Central Research Department (which, soon after, spun off the Vacuum Division). His activity, working for Robert Jepsen, was to study the behavior of the sputter ion pump (in terms of pumping speed and discharge intensity I/P) over a wide range of parameters, such as magnetic field, voltage, anode cell diameter, anode cell length and pressure. Renn Zaphiropoulos joined the Vacuum Division in 1959 and was engaged in scaling up the ion pump from the original appendage pump to a full range of large pumps up to 5000 l/s . His group worked on high voltage feedthroughs, magnets, control units, systems, flanges, valves, sorption pumps and Titanium Sublimation Pumps (TSP). In 1960 the “slotted” titanium cathode, named “Super VacIon Pump”, was introduced on the basis of observations about noble gas pumping mechanism and unstable Argon pumping phenomena. In the same years triode pumps were invented by W.M. Brubaker (Consolidated Electrodynamics Corporation) and Varian, now [[Agilent]], began to sell them in the late ‘60s under the name “Noble Ion Pumps”, then changed the name to “Triode Ion Pumps” in the early ‘70s.
==Penning trap== The basic element of the common ion pump is a [[Penning trap]].<ref>Cambers, A., "Modern Vacuum Physics", CRC Press (2005)</ref> A swirling cloud of [[electron]]s produced by an electric discharge is temporarily stored in the anode region of a Penning trap. These electrons ionize incoming gas atoms and molecules. The resultant swirling ions are accelerated to strike a chemically active cathode (usually titanium).<ref>Weissler, G.L. and Carlson, R.W., editors, ''Methods of Experimental Physics; Vacuum Physics and Technology'', Vol. 14, Academic Press Inc., London (1979)</ref> On impact the accelerated ions will either become buried within the cathode or [[Sputtering|sputter]] cathode material onto the walls of the pump. The freshly sputtered chemically active cathode material acts as a [[getter]] that then evacuates the gas by both [[chemisorption]] and [[physisorption]] resulting in a net pumping action. Inert and lighter gases, such as He and H<sub>2</sub> tend not to sputter and are absorbed by [[physisorption]]. Some fraction of the energetic gas ions (including gas that is not chemically active with the cathode material) can strike the cathode and acquire an electron from the surface, neutralizing it as it rebounds. These rebounding energetic neutrals are buried in exposed pump surfaces.<ref>{{cite book|title=Building Scientific Apparatus|last=Moore|first=J.H.|author2=Davis, C. C. |author3=Coplan, M.A. |author4= Greer, S. |publisher=Westview Press|year=2003|isbn=0-8133-4006-3}}</ref>
Both the pumping rate and capacity of such capture methods are dependent on the specific gas species being collected and the cathode material absorbing it. Some species, such as carbon monoxide, will chemically bind to the surface of a cathode material. Others, such as hydrogen, will diffuse into the metallic structure. In the former example, the pump rate can drop as the cathode material becomes coated. In the latter, the rate remains fixed by the rate at which the hydrogen diffuses.
==Types== There are three main types of ion pumps: the conventional or standard diode pump, the noble diode pump and the [[triode pump]].<ref name=BNL>[http://www.agsrhichome.bnl.gov/RHIC/RAP/rhic_notes/AD-RHIC-1-142/AD-RHIC-125.pdf The pumping of helium and hydrogen by sputter- ion pumps part II]</ref>
==Standard diode pump== A '''standard diode pump''' is a type of ion pump employed in high vacuum processes which contains only chemically active cathodes, in contrast to noble diode pumps.<ref name=BNL/>
==Noble diode pump== A '''noble diode pump''' is a type of ion pump used in high-[[vacuum]] applications that employs both a chemically reactive [[cathode]], such as [[titanium]], and an additional [[cathode]] composed of [[tantalum]]. The tantalum cathode serves as a high-inertia crystal lattice structure for the reflection and burial of neutrals, increasing pumping effectiveness of inert gas ions.<ref name=BNL/> Pumping intermittently high quantities of hydrogen with noble diodes should be done with great care, as hydrogen might over months get re-emitted out of the tantalum.
==Applications== Ion pumps are commonly used in [[ultra-high vacuum]] (UHV) systems, as they can attain ultimate pressures less than 10<sup>−11</sup> [[mbar]].<ref name=Varian/> In contrast to other common UHV pumps, such as [[turbomolecular pump]]s and [[diffusion pump]]s, ion pumps have no moving parts and use no oil. They are therefore clean, need little maintenance, and produce no vibrations. These advantages make ion pumps well-suited for use in [[scanning probe microscopy]] and other high-precision apparatuses.
==Radicals== Recent work has suggested that [[free radicals]] escaping from ion pumps can influence the results of some experiments.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=J. Zikovsky |author2=S. A. Dogel |author3=A. J. Dickie |author4=J. L. Pitters |author5=R. A. Wolkow |title=Reaction of a hydrogen-terminated Si(100) surface in UHV with ion-pump generated radicals|journal=Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology A|volume=27|year=2009|issue=2|page=248|doi=10.1116/1.3071944}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Electroosmotic flow]]
==References== {{Reflist}}<!--added above External links/Sources by script-assisted edit-->
==Sources== * {{cite web|url=http://www.agilent.com/cs/library/periodicals/public/Agilent-Ion-Pump-History.pdf|title=Agilent Ion Pumps, Early History}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.aiv.it/ITA/pubblicazioni/articolo.php?articolo=art4 |title=Gettering and Ion Pumping |work=High-Vacuum Technology: A Practical Guide ({{ISBN|082478197X}}) |last=Hablanian |first=Marsbed |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060509182437/http://www.aiv.it/ita/pubblicazioni/articolo.php?articolo=art4 |archivedate=May 9, 2006 }} * {{cite web|url=http://www.chem.elte.hu/departments/altkem/vakuumtechnika/CERN03.pdf|format=PDF|title=Sputter Ion Pumps|publisher=[[Paul Scherrer Institute]]}}
==External links== * [http://cas.web.cern.ch/cas/Spain-2006/PDFs/Audi.pdf An Introduction to Ion Pumps]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ion Pump (Physics)}} [[Category:Vacuum pumps]]

revision.comment: +[[Category:Plasma instabilities]]; +[[Category:Ionization]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
An '''ionization instability''' is any one of a category of [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] [[Plasma stability|instabilities]] which is mediated by electron-impact [[ionization]]. In the most general sense, an ionization instability occurs from a feedback effect, when electrons produced by ionization go on to produce still more electrons through ionization in a self-reinforcing way.
Ionization instabilities have been seen in such plasma physics apparatus as [[Glow discharge|glow discharges]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Garscadden|first=A.|date=1969|title=Dispersion and Stability of Moving Striations|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.1692748|journal=Physics of Fluids|language=en|volume=12|issue=9|pages=1833|doi=10.1063/1.1692748|issn=0031-9171}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=1976-03-01|title=Review of glow discharge instabilities|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0378436376902679|journal=Physica B+C|language=en|volume=82|issue=1|pages=43–51|doi=10.1016/0378-4363(76)90267-9|issn=0378-4363}}</ref> Penning discharges,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Roth|first=J. Reece|date=1969|title=Experimental Observation of Low-Frequency Oscillations Described by the Plasma Continuity Equations|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.1692284|journal=Physics of Fluids|language=en|volume=12|issue=1|pages=260|doi=10.1063/1.1692284|issn=0031-9171}}</ref> [[Magnetic nozzle|magnetic nozzles]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=J. C.|last2=D'Angelo|first2=N|last3=Merlino|first3=R. L.|date=1990|title=A double layer induced ionisation instability|url=http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0022-3727/23/6/007/meta|journal=Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics|volume=23|pages=682|via=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Aanesland|first=A.|last2=Charles|first2=C.|last3=Lieberman|first3=M. A.|last4=Boswell|first4=R. W.|date=18 August 2006|title=Upstream Ionization Instability Associated with a Current-Free Double Layer|url=https://journals.aps.org/prl/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevLett.97.075003|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=97|issue=7|doi=10.1103/physrevlett.97.075003|issn=0031-9007}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Aanesland|first=A.|last2=Lieberman|first2=M. A.|last3=Charles|first3=C.|last4=Boswell|first4=R. W.|date=December 2006 |title=Experiments and theory of an upstream ionization instability excited by an accelerated electron beam through a current-free double layer|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.2398929|journal=Physics of Plasmas|language=en|volume=13|issue=12|pages=122101|doi=10.1063/1.2398929|issn=1070-664X}}</ref> and [[MHD Generator|MHD generators]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=KERREBROCK|first=J. L.|date=July 1964|title=Nonequilibrium ionization due to electron heating - i - theory|url=https://arc.aiaa.org/doi/10.2514/3.2496|journal=AIAA Journal|language=en-US|volume=2|issue=6|pages=1072–1080|doi=10.2514/3.2496|issn=0001-1452}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Murakami|first=Tomoyuki|last2=Okuno|first2=Yoshihiro|last3=Yamasaki|first3=Hiroyuki|date=9 May 2005|title=Suppression of ionization instability in a magnetohydrodynamic plasma by coupling with a radio-frequency electromagnetic field|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.1926410|journal=Applied Physics Letters|language=en|volume=86|issue=19|pages=191502|doi=10.1063/1.1926410|issn=0003-6951}}</ref><ref>Velikhov, E. P., A. M. Dykhne, and I. Ya. Shipuk. “Ionization Instability of a Plasma with Hot Electrons.” From the 5th Symposium on the Ionization of Gases, Yugoslavia, 1965. <nowiki>https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19670016557.pdf</nowiki>.</ref> Ionization instabilities may occur in magnetized or unmagnetized<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Akhiezer|first=A. I.|last2=Akhiezer|first2=A. I.|last3=Angeleiko|first3=V. V.|date=1969|title=A New Kind of Instability in a Partially Ionized Plasma|url=http://www.jetp.ac.ru/cgi-bin/e/index/e/30/3/p476?a=list|journal=Soviet Journal of Experimental and Theoretical Physics|volume=30|pages=476|via=}}</ref> plasma. They occur mostly when the plasma is relatively cold and only partially ionized, so that there is a lot of neutral gas mixed in with the plasma.
== In a glow discharge == [[File:Glow discharge regions.jpg|thumb|Striations formed by ionization instability can be seen to the right of this glow discharge.]] {{Main|Glow discharge}} A glow discharge is a plasma-containing apparatus in which the plasma is formed by a large voltage placed across a rarefied gas. Glow discharges are used for electric lighting and materials processing. In a glow discharge, ionization instability takes the form of [[Glow discharge#Regions|striations]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Garscadden|first=A.|date=1969|title=Dispersion and Stability of Moving Striations|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.1692748|journal=Physics of Fluids|language=en|volume=12|issue=9|pages=1833|doi=10.1063/1.1692748|issn=0031-9171}}</ref> or bands of enhanced and suppressed light production. The distance between each striation is the distance required for an electron to gain enough energy to ionize a neutral gas particle.
== In a magnetic nozzle == {{Main|Magnetic nozzle}} A magnetic nozzle is an apparatus through which plasma flows, in which the plasma is constricted by a magnetic field. Magnetic nozzles are used in [[Electric propulsion]] to enhance the thrust produced by a stream of plasma. In magnetic nozzles, ionization instability is caused by ionization downstream of the nozzle, causing electrons born there to migrate upstream, counter to the direction of flow. This the plasma flow rate and energy through the nozzle to oscillate.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
== In an MHD generator == {{Main|MHD Generator}} An MHD generator is an apparatus through which hot gas flows, in which the gas is ionized and a magnetic field is used to extract flow energy as electrical energy. MHD generators were studied mostly in the 1960s and 1970s to increase the efficiency of fossil-fueled and nuclear-fission power plants.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Harris|first=L. P.|last2=Moore|first2=G. E.|date=1971|title=Combustion-MHD Power Generation for Central Stations|url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/4074561|journal=IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems|volume=90|pages=2030|via=}}</ref> In MHD generators, the specific kind of magnetized ionization instability is called the [[electrothermal instability]]. It was discovered by [[Evgeny Velikhov]] in 1962. The added electrical resistance caused by ionization instability thwarted a research effort to lower the required temperature by heating electrons preferentially.<ref name=":3" />
== References ==
[[Category:Plasma instabilities]] [[Category:Ionization]]
